newsitem.title: HUNGARY: SKALA STEPS UP EFFORTS TO GAIN CLIENTS.
newsitem.headline: SKALA STEPS UP EFFORTS TO GAIN CLIENTS.

text.p: Hungarian retailer Skala Aruhazi Kft, main member of Skala group , said it was stepping up its efforts to gain regular clients as it does not share analysts' optimism about a recovery in consumption.
"Despite optimistic forecasts I don't really think that Hungarian consumption will grow," the diversified retailer's managing director Janos Halasz told a news conference on Thursday.
Skala Aruhazi's regular customer system, to be fully operational by October, is expected to generate extra revenues for the company, he said.

"We expect hundreds of millions of forints in additional turnover against tens of millions of forints in costs," Halasz said. "We aren't impatient, the most important is to have a loyal clientele," he said.

Regular clients participating in the system as a result of a six-month recruitment programme starting on March 25, will receive different benefits from October in all of Skala Aruhazi Kft's department stores.
Analysts expect Hungary's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) to rise by around two and a half percent in 1997, after a flat growth last year, propelled by rising investments and recovering consumption.
In its preliminary unconsolidated 1996 earnings report, Skala said Skala Aruhazi Kft generated 8.81 billion forints sales revenues compared to 7.29 billion in 1995.
The group's total unconsolidated revenue amounted to 12.59 billion forints in 1996 from 10.79 billion in 1995.
On the Budapest Stock Exchange Skala shares remained untraded on Thursday but closed at 1,800 forints on Wednesday.
